results:
Based on the search results, I found important information about Bruno Schulz's Polish translation of Franz Kafka's "The Trial" (Der Process/Proces) from 1936:

## Key findings about the 1936 Polish edition:

The book was published in Warsaw in 1936 by Towarzystwo Wydawnicze "Rój" (though one source mentions "Zdrój" publishing house). It was 284 pages, with a format of 12.5x18.5 cm.

This was the first Polish edition of this masterpiece of 20th-century world literature, featuring an afterword by Bruno Schulz.

## Important revelation about the translation:

The first Polish edition was translated by Józefina Szelińska, with corrections made by Bruno Schulz, and the translation was published under his name. More specifically, according to research by J. Ficowski, contrary to what was printed on the title page, the translation was done by B. Schulz's fiancée Józefina Szelińska, and he only provided her with advice and guidance.

The book included a commentary/afterword by Bruno Schulz on pages 279-284, which contemporary readers viewed as the translator's commentary.

This 1936 edition has become legendary in Polish literary history, as Bruno Schulz is credited with creating a brilliant translation of Kafka's "The Trial", even though the actual translation work was primarily done by Józefina Szelińska. The edition remains highly valued by collectors and was reprinted multiple times with Schulz's illustrations in later years.
